contentItems.name: Assess your current skill level
contentItems.text:
For those nurses out there already working in primary health care, have you ever felt under-valued? Under-utilised? Not sure where to start when planning your CPD? 

Take the self-assessment and discover your strengths and areas to grow in relation to your practice. 

Receive a personalized report that provides you with a breakdown of your strengths, and provides suggestions on new approaches to continue your professional growth.

 Use this report to plan your CPD, demonstrate to your employer your worth or even to help you understand how crucial your skills and knowledge are to the team.

 You will also receive a CPD certificate for undertaking this professional reflective activity.

contentItems.name: intro
contentItems.text:
During the consultation to develop this framework, we listened to nurses (over 700 in total!) talk about the difficulties they've faced in establishing a long-term and satisfying career in primary health care nursing.

But along with these stories of frustration, we also heard many positive stories from veteran nurses with enviable primary health care nursing careers. With passion and resilience they faced their challenges head on and found ways to overcome them.

Their stories were inspirational to us. This section hopes to gather that insight and hard won wisdom into a single resource to provide guidance and support for nurses trying to find their way in primary health care nursing.

My Nursing Future.com.au Privacy Policy

 

About us and this Policy

Australian Primary Health Care Nursing Association Inc (APNA, we, us or our), owner and operator of the ‘My Nursing Future’ website (the Website), is committed to the protection of your personal information.

This privacy policy (this Policy) deals with the way we will collect, use, disclose, store and protect your personal information. This Policy also describes the way in which you may access or correct the personal information we hold about you, and how to contact us is you have any complaints in relation to your privacy.

 

Our legal obligations

We will handle your personal information according to law, and we are bound by the Australian Privacy Principles (APPs) contained in the Privacy Act 1988 (Cth) (Privacy Act).

The APPs set out strict requirements for the handling of your personal information.

 

What is ‘personal information’?

This Policy applies to our handling of personal information. ‘Personal information’ means information or an opinion about an identified individual, or an individual who is reasonably identifiable, whether the information is true or not and whether the information is recorded in a material form or not.

Personal information includes ‘sensitive information’, which is a particular type of personal information. Sensitive information includes information about you such as your membership of a professional or trade association, your religious beliefs or affiliations, philosophical beliefs and racial or ethnic origin.

 

Why do we collect your personal information?

The Website allows you to obtain advice, support and guidance on career progression and opportunities in primary health care nursing.

We collect your personal information so that you can effectively use the Website.

We collect your name, email and APNA membership status in order to link it to your current profile on the Website.  We also collect this information as part of APNAs prospective member contact list and for APNA marketing purposes.

How do we collect your personal information?

We will only collect your personal information through your use of the Website.

We will collect your personal information in a lawful and fair way and in a manner that is not unreasonably intrusive.

We only collect your personal information where it is reasonably necessary for our activities in providing the Website to you.

We will only collect your personal information and sensitive information where you have consented through your use of the Website, or otherwise in accordance with the law.

When we collect your personal information, we will take reasonable steps to ensure that you are made aware of the details of the collection, including the purposes for which the information was collected, the organisations (if any) to which the information will be disclosed, and notify you that this Policy contains details on how you may access or correct your information, or raise any complaints.  We will whenever practical, provide you with this information through the Website.

 


 

What types of personal information do we usually collect?

We collect personal information such as:

·       your name;

·       your email address;

·       your highest qualification;

·       the principal area and setting of your current workplace (includes sector and job role – for example a practice nurse working in general practice);

·       your years of work in primary healthcare;

·       the postcode where you work or live; and

·       your year of birth

 

How do we use your personal information?

We use your personal information for the main purpose of providing you with advice, support and guidance on career progression and opportunities in primary health care nursing through the Website.

We may also use your personal information for purposes which are directly related to providing you with the Website, in circumstances where you would reasonably expect us to use your information for these purposes, such as for registration and administration purposes.

We use your name, email and your APNA membership status to link it to your current profile on the Website. We also use this information for APNA prospective member contact list and APNA marketing purposes.

Do we disclose your personal information to others?

We respect the privacy of your personal information and we will take reasonable steps to keep it safe.

We will not disclose your personal information to any third parties unless you have consented through your use of the Website, or we are otherwise permitted or required to do so by law.

In accordance with the law, we will only disclose your personal information without your consent in circumstances such as where we reasonably believe this is necessary to prevent or lessen or prevent a serious threat to the life, health or safety of any individual, or to public health or safety.

 

Will we disclose your personal information overseas?

We will not disclose your personal information to any recipient that is located overseas.

 

How do we hold and protect your personal information?

We will protect your privacy and the security of your personal information by taking steps to ensure that your personal information is protected against misuse, interference and loss, and unauthorised access, modification or disclosure.

These steps include using a personal identification number or password to ensure that only you or persons you have authorised can access your information through the Website.

We also use a variety of physical and technological security measures to protect the personal information we hold.

We may hold your personal information in a number of ways including electronically and in physical format.

We will store your personal information in secure servers located in Australia which might be provided by a third party provider. We may need to give the third party provider access to personal information to enable the support and maintenance of our Website.

When your personal information is no longer required, we will take steps to securely destroy the information or to ensure that the information is de-identified.

 

Quality of the personal information we hold

We take reasonable steps to ensure that the personal information we collect, use and disclose is accurate, up-to-date, complete and relevant. You can assist us in keeping your accurate by updating your personal information through the Website when there are any changes to your details.

Can you access and correct your personal information?

You may request to access the personal information that we hold about you using our contact details below.

In certain circumstances, we may refuse to allow you access to your personal information where this is authorised by the law, such as where the request is frivolous or vexatious; providing access would have an unreasonable impact on the privacy of other individuals; providing access would pose a serious threat to the life or health of any person or to public health or safety; or giving access would be unlawful.

We take all reasonable steps to ensure that the personal information we collect, use and disclose is accurate, up-to-date and complete, relevant and not misleading.

If you believe that the personal information we hold about you requires correction, you may request that the information be corrected using our contact details below.

If we refuse your request for access or correction, we will provide you with reasons for the refusal in writing, and details about how you may complain about the decision.

 

Cookies

We also collect data through our use of ‘cookies’ and other internet technologies. ‘Cookies’ are small data files that your internet browser stores on your computer or other mobile device.  Cookies are stored in order for your internet browser to navigate a website and the cookies themselves cannot collect any information stored on your computer or other device.

We will not use cookies to collect your identifying personal information. The cookies may collect statistical information about your visit to the Website (such as the pages you visit on the Website) in order to remember your preferences and provide your with a more user-friendly experience.

Some of the cookies may be ‘session’ cookies, which will be deleted when you have ended your internet session and close your browser. Other cookies are ‘persistent’ cookies which are stored on your computer or device until its designated expiration date (e.g. 6 months or 2 years).

The default settings of most internet browsers is to accept cookies automatically, but you can actively delete or disable cookies by changing your browser settings.

 

What information is not personal information?

Information where we have removed any material that would reasonably identify a person (‘de-identified information’), is not personal information.

We may use the personal information you provide, in de-identified and in aggregate form (not de-identified at the individual level, but aggregated across multiple individuals) to support decisions about health workforce planning and to support decisions about promoting, disseminating and evaluating the My Nursing Futures.com.au website.

We may share de-identified information about you (and other users of the Website) with third parties, such as government agencies such as the federal Department of Health; Primary Health Networks and state government departments such as the Victorian Department of Health and Human Services and other nursing and health workforce organisations.

We may also share de-identified information, in aggregate form, as part of the evaluation, dissemination and promotion of the My Nursing Futures.com.au website.  De-identified information, in aggregate form, may be presented in aggregate and shared through journal articles; published and unpublished reports; in hard-copy and online through APNA’s website, newsletters, social media, through webinars and in APNA presentations.  

The sharing of de-identified information with these third parties and as part of the evaluation of the My Nursing Futures.com.au website will be for the purpose of future planning for the health workforce, for health care and in the ongoing promotion of the My Nursing Futures.com.au website.

  


 

Complaints

We respect your privacy and we take all complaints and concerns regarding privacy very seriously.

If you have any complaints or concerns regarding the way we handle your personal information please contact us using the details below.

We will investigate your complaint using our internal processes, under which we will assess your complaint and respond to you within a reasonable time.

If you are not satisfied with the outcome of our investigation, you may wish to contact the Commonwealth Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC). See www.oaic.gov.au. 

 

Our contact details

If you:

·       would like to request access to or correction of your personal information;

·       would like further information about our privacy policies and procedures; or

·       have any complaints or concerns regarding your privacy,

please contact us using the following details:

The Privacy Officer

Australian Primary Health Care Nurses Association

Level 2

159 Dorcas Street

South Melbourne, Vic 3205

 

or

 

Email the Privacy Officer at: framework@apna.asn.au

 

Changes to this Policy

We may revise this Policy from time to time. We will update you on any changes to this Policy through the Website.

contentItems.name: About the Career and Education Framework
contentItems.text:
Do you know what it takes to be a nurse in primary health care? We often hear from nurses who think primary health care is where you go when you want to slow down or reduce your workload. So is this true? Far from it.

Talk to a nurse working in primary health care and they will tell you how challenging and rewarding their work is, how they love being part of their patient’s story, and how every nurse’s journey into and through primary health care is different.

Primary health care offers a diverse, dynamic and fulfilling career with ongoing opportunities to evolve professionally and make a difference to people’s lives.

It is often fast-paced, autonomous, allows you to work with a range of health professionals, advocate for your patients, and think outside the box to develop and deliver innovative models of care.

The opportunities in primary health care are vast, and some are still in their infancy. The scope of practice for nurses in primary health care continues to evolve and grow, and enables nurses to showcase more than just their clinical expertise. It drives nurses to expand their non-clinical skillsets by providing opportunities to interact with the community to improve health outcomes, understand referral pathways and act as the vital connection in the patient journey as care coordinator, and to influence by representing the profession on health and government committees.

My Nursing Future provides nurses and future nurses with a guide into the different realms of primary health care. My Nursing Future is the product of the Career and Education Framework project, a nursing workforce initiative proudly developed by the Australian Primary Health Care Nurses Association (APNA) and funded by the Australian Government Department of Health under the Nursing in Primary Health Care Program.

The Framework has been developed in consultation with more than 1,000 nurses, health professionals and health experts. APNA would like to thank all of the individuals involved in the development and delivery of the Framework.
contentItems.title: About the Career and Education Framework

contentItems.text:
The Framework has been designed to provide current and future nurses with an insight into the roles of nurses working in primary health care. The self-assessment acts as the interactive version of the Framework.

To use the Framework either download the PDF or complete the self-assessment. The self-assessment takes 60 minutes and is a professional reflection activity that enables nurses currently working in primary health care to identify their strengths and areas to grow.

Please note, the self-assessment is a self-reflection activity and the results are not a formal qualification, nor does it enable you to dictate your discipline of nursing. It simply allows you to understand what level you practice at. You must still abide by the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia standards and guidelines and Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency registration requirements.

For further information please refer to the Terms and Conditions .
contentItems.title: How do I use it?

contentItems.text:
The self-assessment enables you to self-reflect on your nursing practice and identify your strengths and areas to grow. The beauty of the self-reflection activity is that it will deliver you a personalised report which can be used in a number of ways.

·         To assist you to actively plan your CPD

·         To showcase your skills, knowledge and experience to your employer

·         Results can be built into your nursing role and key performance indicators with your manager

·         To assist your search for different career opportunities in primary health care

·         Identify areas you would like to progress and extend your scope of practice

Did you find the self-assessment useful? Tell us how the self-assessment and the personalised report helped you, and how you used it to guide your career in primary health care nursing.
contentItems.title: How does it benefit me?

contentItems.text: The self-assessment and the personalised report can show your employer how your skills can be better utilised in the team, assist in your performance review and set career goals with your manager, highlight areas you would like further education in, and how your employer’s investment in your CPD can benefit the team, patients and community.
contentItems.title: How can it benefit my employer?

contentItems.text:
Where do we begin? The Framework was developed using an evidence-based and rigorous approach.

It all began with a literature review. This was used to identify what career and education pathways were available for nurses and health professionals (both national and international), and how the Australian nursing workforce could benefit from a similar framework for nurses working in primary health care.

From here on, an environmental scan was conducted to understand the areas of primary health care in which nurses had a predominant role. This identifying settings such as refugee health, community health, Aboriginal Health Services, general practice, correctional health, residential care and many more.

So now the team had an idea of what other Frameworks looked like and the areas of primary health care nursing that should be further investigated, but we still needed to learn about what the Framework needed to address and how current and future nurses would access this information.

A consultation was conducted from early 2016 through to July 2017. This included a number of methods; face-to-face workshops, interviews, prototype testing, online consultation, focus groups and conference presentations. Key participants included those with expertise across a range of primary health care settings and with a variety of focus areas, including clinical, policy, management, research and education.

The need for a Framework and resources was clearly articulated by all participants and demonstrated a current gap, while outlining the many and varied potential impacts the Framework would have on recruitment and retention of nurses in primary health care settings.

Most significantly, all stakeholders saw value in the Framework to improve the perceived value and professionalism of the nursing role in primary health care. Other major themes consistent across the range of consultations included the positive impact the Framework would have on strengthening undergraduate nursing cirriculums and clinical placements, the development of transition support programs, supporting recruitment and retention, identifying relevant formal and informal education pathways and options, describing the breadth of nursing roles, the opportunities for career progression, and as a promotional tool.

Current and future nurses told us the way they access career and education information is predominantly via mobile phone. So we invited nurses to work with APNA to develop a mobile-responsive website which would contain resources, information, contacts and visual career pathways, for nurses to explore and navigate the potential of working in primary health care.

Everything down to the My Nursing Future logo, the colours in the self-assessment report, the wording in the self-assessment, videos of nurses working in primary health care, career advice articles, and the words of wisdom, were all developed by current and future nurses.

APNA formally acknowledges all of the organisations and individuals involved in this project. We also acknowledge the project team who has worked tirelessly to represent your ideas and knowledge on the primary health care nursing workforce – Emily Wheeler, Dr Jacqui Richmond, Linda Govan and Brie Woods.
contentItems.title: How was it developed?

contentItems.text:
It would be great to hear your feedback! Tell us…

1.     Why primary health care nursing is important?

2.     How you got to where you are now in primary health care?

3.     What are the words of wisdom you would offer people just starting out or thinking of entering primary health care nursing?

4.     What barriers are currently in your way to entering primary health care or progressing your career?

5.     What are the great education opportunities that nurses in primary health care should know about?

6.     Would you like APNA to come and chat you your team, students or nursing community about primary health care nursing?

If you have anything to say, get in touch with APNA and be part of this exciting journey.

domains.name: Clinical Care
domains.title: Clinical Care
domains.text:
Holistic, person-centred, culturally safe nursing practice delivered through a social model of health and continuing throughout the individual's health journey.

Nursing practice is underpinned by the concept of health and wellness, is delivered within and in partnership with the individual and the community and in collaboration with the interdisciplinary team.

Clinical care includes preventive health, early intervention, chronic disease management and end of life planning, within a framework of assessment, planning, implementation and evaluation.

domains.name: Clinical Care (EN)
domains.title: Clinical Care
domains.text:
Holistic, person-centred, culturally safe nursing practice delivered through a social model of health and continuing throughout the individual's health journey.

Nursing practice is underpinned by the concept of health and wellness, is delivered within and in partnership with the individual and the community and in collaboration with the interdisciplinary team.

Clinical care includes preventive health, early intervention, chronic disease management and end of life planning, within a framework of assessment, planning, implementation and evaluation.

domains.name: Education
domains.title: Education
domains.text:
Practice that involves the enhancement of the knowledge and skills of health professionals and the community, to promote quality health care and improve health outcomes.

This involves recognition of existing knowledge, skills and capacity, while engaging communities to promote wellness and manage illness or disability. It is inclusive of informal and formal education to health professionals and the community.

domains.name: Education (EN)
domains.title: Education
domains.text:
Practice that involves the enhancement of the knowledge and skills of health professionals and the community, to promote quality health care and improve health outcomes.

This involves recognition of existing knowledge, skills and capacity, while engaging communities to promote wellness and manage illness or disability. It is inclusive of informal and formal education to health professionals and the community.

domains.name: Leadership
domains.title: Leadership
domains.text:
Demonstrates leadership in actively promoting the role, value and professionalism of nursing, specifically the role of the nurse in primary health care.

Activities include driving change, acting as a resource for professional organisations, groups and individuals, and facilitating and engaging in the dissemination of knowledge beyond own setting.

domains.name: Optimising health systems
domains.title: Optimising health systems
domains.text:
Contributes to the optimal functioning of the primary health care setting, coordinating care and assisting people to navigate through the health system and across care transitions, to improve health outcomes.

Seeks to enhance systems at an organisational level, process level and the level of the individual accessing care.

domains.name: Research
domains.title: Research
domains.text:
Actively supports the implementation of evidence into practice where this has been shown to improve health outcomes and the quality of nursing care.

Seeks the delivery of high quality health care through the practice of inquiry, quality improvement, research and evaluation and promotes innovative, evidence informed problem-solving. This includes identifying opportunities for research and resources to conduct research in the primary health care setting.

domains.name: Research (EN)
domains.title: Research
domains.text:
Actively supports the implementation of evidence into practice where this has been shown to improve health outcomes and the quality of nursing care.

This includes identifying opportunities for research and resources to conduct research in the primary health care setting.

sectorRn.intro:
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have higher rates of chronic disease than non-Indigenous Australians. The continued focus on prevention and management of chronic disease is crucial to close the gap in life expectancy. The Aboriginal Medical Health Services is a critical provider of primary health care to the Aboriginal and Torre Strait Islander communities.

Aboriginal Medical Health Services work together with the local Aboriginal and Torre Strait Islander community to offer a range of services such as; health screening tests, chronic disease management, illness prevention, counselling, healthy lifestyle advice, adult and child health checks, health care plans and referrals.

Aboriginal Medical Health Services range from large multi-functional services employing several medical practitioners and providing a wide range of services, to small services without medical practitioners, which rely on Aboriginal health workers and/or nurses to provide the bulk of primary care services, often with a preventive, health education focus.1

The nursing team work closely with the Aboriginal Health workers, general practitioners, and other health workers to assist with health assessments, health promotion and conducting care plans. Nurses working in this sector also work closely with the community to deliver culturally safe health care.

sectorRn.intro:
Nurses working in community health work with people from many different cultures and ethnicity, including Aboriginal and Torre Strait Islander people. These nurses also work with disadvantaged and disempowered people. 

Working with their local communities, nurses in community health work to prevent illness and promote health across the lifespan by identifying barriers to healthy lifestyles and general wellness. They work in partnership with families and communities to empower individuals accessing care to change unhealthy lifestyles and also provide post acute care to people in their homes.

It is important that a nurse considering working in community health, are be able to assume responsibility and a leadership role, be able to take initiative in emergencies, have strong communication skills, can work autonomously and as part of a team, poses patience and discretion when providing health care, and is open to working in a clinical setting and also working off-site (i.e. conducting home visits).

It is often noted that nurses in community health provide an interpretative bridge between the acute sector and the community. They are pivotal in using a social model of health to advocate and give a voice to the community accessing health care. In a system which is often complex and hard to navigate, nurses in community health are able to simplify the health systems, referral pathways and access to care by coordinating and guiding the patient’s care.

Nurse in community health work in an interdisciplinary team which can include, but is not limited to, mental health nurses, podiatrists, general practitioners, psychologists, women’s health nurses, Aboriginal Health workers, allied health and hospital services.

sectorRn.intro:
Correctional health has been described as an ‘emergency department crossed with a general practice’. Correctional health nurses provide healthcare to those incarcerated in the criminal justice system in a variety of settings such as jails, prisons, and juvenile detention centers. The nursing team are often the first health professional prisoners will see in regards to health care. 

As soon as a prisoner enters the prison, the nurse works with the health care team to conduct a physical and mental health assessment. This ensures that health care team are aware of the prisoner’s health and medication needs. 

Correctional health nurses work with a stagnant health population. Because of this, nurses are able to have longer contact with the patient population leading to management of chronic conditions and a more stable health care environment. Despite the fact that correctional nurses work with individuals that commit crimes, they must be able to treat each one with objectivity and respect, as well as compassion and sometimes assertiveness.

Nursing tasks in correctional health could include, and are not limited to, nurse-led clinics, health promotion, liaising with the health team, coordinating care, conducting health assessments, alcohol and drug treatment, providing immunisations, emergency responses and chronic disease management.

One of the most important relationships is between the nursing team and the correctional officers. The two professions must work closely with each other to ensure emergency situations are managed and the health and safety of the health care team is always assured. Due to the process’ in place and the working relationship with the custodial officers, nurses often feel safe in the correctional health environment.

sectorRn.intro:
Drug and Alcohol Nurses specialise in the identification, management, intervention and support of communities and individuals using drugs and alcohol (sometimes referred to as alcohol, tobacco and other drug (ATOD) issues). 

They respond to drug and alcohol related conditions and their comorbidities (including mental health problems) and use a holistic person-centred approach to alleviate issues surrounding dependence and addiction. Drug and Alcohol Nurses work in a range of settings in primary health care including community health care centres, outreach and general practice.

Drug and Alcohol Nurses use various skills within an interdisciplinary team to assist individuals, their families, and broader communities who are facing drug and alcohol issues, including counselling and support, medication adherence, withdrawal management, psychosocial support, health promotion, harm minimisation, advocacy, individual and group education, case management and care planning.

sectorRn.intro:
A general practice nurse is a registered nurse or an enrolled nurse who is employed by, or whose services are otherwise retained by a general practice. There are approximately 12,322 nurses working within general practice (AIHW Nursing and Midwifery Workforce Report 2014) with around 63 per cent of general practices employing at least one nurse (Australian Medicare Local Alliance General Practice Nurse National Survey Report 2012).

General practice nursing is the fastest growing area within the healthcare sector and covers many areas of nursing practice including; lifestyle education, aged care, women’s health, men’s health, infection control, chronic disease management including cardiovascular, asthma and COPD care, immunisation, cancer management, mental health, maternal and child health, health promotion, population health, diabetes, wound management, Aboriginal health and much more.

With the return of focus to the primary health care sector, general practice nurses are increasingly exerting a critical role in delivering continuous care to their patients that results in improved health outcomes. Nurses are considered to be a key part of the forthcoming changes in the delivery of primary health care in this country.

General practice nursing offers a great opportunity to work at the forefront of primary care in Australia in a variety of contexts, such as rural, urban, large or small practices or with discrete populations, such as migrant or refugee groups. Working collaboratively in a team setting as a respected health professional has ensured that general practice nursing is a valid and rewarding career choice for many nurses.

sectorRn.intro: Nurses working within the acute sector / hospital setting (which sits outside the realms of primary health care) do so in a range of roles and clinical areas which also require unique skill sets. The nursing role can include perioperative nursing, clinical specialty or general ward nursing, outpatient departments, ICU and emergency nursing.  Although the nursing duties vary from area to area they also include aspects of patient education, individual health promotion and communicating with medical staff and allied health. It also includes direct patient care such as administering medication, observing and monitoring patient’s conditions and assisting patients with personal care. Within the hospital exists a number of roles for advancement including working as a Clinical Nurse Specialist (CNS), Nurse Unit Manager (NUM) and Clinical Nurse Educator (CNE).

sectorRn.intro:
Maternal and Child Health Nurses (MCHN), work with families and communities in a variety of primary health care settings (including community health centres, general practice and aboriginal heath centres), and provide a range of services within health facilities and through home visits.

MCHN focus on prevention, promotion, early detection and interventions relating to the health and wellbeing of young children 0 to 5 years of age and their families. 

MCHN provide information on a variety of topics relevant to young families, including parenting and child health, development and learning, child behaviour, breastfeeding, sleeping and behavioural problems, nutrition, immunisation and family planning. 

The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare and the Australian Association of Maternal and Child Health Nurses indicate there are significant workforce shortages in qualified MCH nurses in Australia.

sectorRn.intro:
Men’s health nurses work across a range of settings in primary health care and have a focus on creating environments which allow men to access and better engage with the health care sector. Nurses working in this area seek to provide culturally appropriate and accessible health care, specifically for males, with an aim to decrease the inequities in health care between genders whilst focusing on at risk populations.

Men’s health nurses utilise a broad range of knowledge and skills including health promotion, clinical coordination, case management, observation and assessment, sexual and reproductive health, workplace health programs, and chronic condition management.

Men’s health nurses in primary health care are a relatively new standalone role and represent an exciting avenue through which the disparities in health outcomes can be improved by a targeted and gender specific approach to primary health care.

sectorRn.intro:
Mental health nurses work across a broad range of primary health care settings and provide a variety of psychological services and health promoting activities. 

Mental health nursing is varied and requires a broad set of specialist skills including mental health promotion and prevention, mental health assessment and intervention, education, medication management and education, counselling and psychotherapy, and direct nursing care.

Mental health nurses work collaboratively with a wide range other health professionals as a multidisciplinary team. Mental health nurses work in partnership with individuals and communities to empower individuals with mental health conditions and regularly provide centre based care and home/ community visits. 

The Mental Health Services Australia 2017 Workforce Report indicated that there were 20,834 mental health nurses in Australia working across acute and primary health care settings.

sectorRn.intro:
Nursing in public health is complementary to other healthcare, as the focus is the health of the population rather than the health needs of the individual. Nurses working in public health primarily address communicable diseases, such as HIV and tuberculosis, through disease surveillance, case management, contact tracing and illness prevention, with the aim of improving the health of the community. They also implement health promotion, primary prevention and health education programs. 

Nurses in public health can work in a variety of settings and contexts such as federal, state/territory and local health departments, non-government organisations, schools, community health centres, and general practice. They specialise in the planning, delivery and evaluation of population health programs, including immunisation strategies, often targeting priority populations. They are integral to population health planning and policy development.   

Nurses in public health are sometimes referred to as Community Health Nurses or other role titles such as Immunisation, Infection Control or Communicable Disease Control Nurses.

sectorRn.intro:
People from refugee background including humanitarian refugees and asylum seekers are amongst the most vulnerable people in the world. They may suffer from diseases and conditions rarely seen in Australia (including malaria, tuberculosis, schistosomiasis or other intestinal parasites and fungal skin infections 1 1; 2; 3) and some have mental health issues related to a background of torture and trauma,untreated health conditions, injuries, or nutritional deficits exacerbated through poor living conditions and lack of access to treatment.4; 5; 6,7 

Nurses specialising in Refugee Health, work collaboratively with the newly arrived families and individuals accessing care in partnerships with  health and community care professionals. These may include general practitioners, counsellors, allied health staff, settlement workers, community services and acute hospitals. The Refugee Health Nurses  coordinate person-centred health management and support refugees and asylum seekers to access appropriate services through referrals and establish referral pathways.The nurses  facilitate the development of health knowledge and skills with people from refugee and asylum seeker background in key areas such as health literacy and advocacy.

This position has a focus on supporting the needs of individuals, extended families and the community. The work is underpinned by a human rights approach and a holistic response to health.

References:

1. Benson, J., & Davis, J (2007). Malaria in the Australian refugee population. Aust Fam Physician, 36, 639-641, 656.

2. Benson J, Donohue W (2007). Hepatitis in refugees who settle in Australia. Aust Fam Physician, 36, 719-727.

3. Benson J. Skull S (2007). Hiding from the sun - vitamin D deficiency in refugees. Aust Fam Physician, 36, 355-357.

4. Gould G, Viney K, Greenwood M, et al (2010). A multidisciplinary primary healthcare clinic for newly arrived humanitarian entrants in regional NSW: model of service delivery and summary of preliminary findings. Aust N Z J Public Health, 34, 326-329.

5. Benson J, Smith, MM (2007). Early health assessment of refugees. Aust Fam Physician, 36, 41-43.

6. Tiong AC, Patel MS, Gardiner J. et al (2006). Health issues in newly arrived African refugees attending general practice clinics in Melbourne. Med J Aust, 185, 602-606.

7. Jackson Bowers E, Cheng (2010). Meeting the Primary Health Care Needs of Refugees and Asylum Seekers. PHCRIS, RESEARCH ROUNDup Issue 16. Adelaide: Primary Health Care Research & Information Service.

sectorRn.intro:
Nurses working in residential care primarily provide healthcare to an elderly population. This population more commonly have co-morbidities (including dementia) and chronic disease. 

The nursing workforce in residential care will keep on growing as Australia faces a larger and larger aging population over the next 20 - 30 years.  This means that skilled nurses will always be in demand and this sector of nursing can be a great career option.

The nursing role in residential care is exceptionally comprehensive. Some of the nursing duties during a shift can include: registered nurses giving medication to residents, advocating for the resident’s health, provide holistic care, care planning (including advanced care planning), wound care, chronic disease management, check their resident’s vitals, liaise with other members of the health professional team to coordinate care (e.g. physiotherapist, psychiatrist, general practitioner, mental health nurses, etc) prepare handover notes for other nursing and health professional members, provide guidance and delegate tasks to Enrolled Nurses and Assistants in Nursing team members.

A very important component for nurses working in residential care is liaising with the resident’s family/carer. The moment a resident moves into a residential care, there is a settling in period, for which a resident may need support from their family/carer and the health professional team, in particular nurses, in order to make the transition as smooth as possible.  At times there may be problems and issues that new or even established residents face, and that’s when having a nurse skilled in family liaison can be very helpful for the resident.

Not only does the resident need support when dealing with a problem at the residential care facility, but their family/carer may need support as well to help understand their relative’s/loved ones fears or concerns.  A skilled nurse can help the resident and their family/carer in helping to solve the problem and making sure that everyone is happy with the outcome.

sectorRn.intro:
School nurses work in primary and secondary schools to provide clinical and educational assistance to students. School nurses work holistically providing medical surveillance, disease management, emergency preparation, case management, and health promotion and education in the school setting.

School nurses facilitate collaboration between teachers, students and their parents, and other health professionals to ensure optimal health outcomes for at risk students. School nurses also play a critical role in providing occupational health and safety risk assessments to ensuring safe working environments for teachers, and students welfare.

School nurse’s role includes; health screening and assessments, health education and promotion, providing education, immunisation, general nursing tasks, first aid case management, multidisciplinary liaison, occupational health and safety assessments, mental health assessment and counselling. 

School nurses are the major primary health care providers for the 5-18 year old age group.

sectorRn.intro:
Nursing in Sexual and Reproductive Health is a specialised area of primary health care nursing that focuses on the sexual and reproductive health of individuals and communities. These nurses work in a range of settings including, but not limited to, community health care centres, sexual health clinics, general practice, fertility and termination clinics.

A wide range of population groups are engaged to ensure optimal sexual and reproductive health and wellbeing and to promote population based initiatives, such as safer sex and regular sexual health check-ups. Sexual and Reproductive Health Nurses also specialise in family planning education, fertility and contraception cervical screening programs, continence care, breast health and menopause education and advice.

Nurses working in Sexual and Reproductive Health use a variety of specialist skills including assessment, care planning, advocacy, health promotion and education, disease surveillance and monitoring and case management.

sectorRn.intro:
Work Health and Safety (WHS) or occupational Health nurses are specialist nurses with qualifications in occupational health. They work across a range of sectors including mining, manufacturing and production facilities and in health centres. 

WHS nurses provide for and deliver health and safety programs to workers, work populations and community groups. WHS nurses focus on the injury and illness prevention, health promotion and restoration, and protection from occupational related hazards. WHS nurse’s work both with employees and employers to ensure a work place has no negative impacts on individuals and work to ensure optimal health amongst workplaces.

WHS nurses undertake the following roles; coordinate and deliver health services and health programs, work in multidisciplinary teams to prevent injury and provide injury rehabilitation, advocate for employee’s rights to a safe work place, provide health education and disease management programs with a view to enhance self-management, routinely monitor the health of work places and individuals within them.
sectorRn.careerPathways:
[{"level":0,"title":"Practice nurse","text":"

Health assessments, education regarding safe work practices, chronic disease assessment, general nursing duties, health promotion.

"},{"level":1,"title":"WHS nurse/ occupational health nurse","text":"

Have completed or currently undertaking further formal qualifications in WHS/ occupational health nurse, work health safety assessments, manage safety of a workplace, policy and guideline implementation, education, health promotion, immunisation. 

"},{"level":2,"title":"WHS nurse/ occupational health nurse","text":"

Completed formal qualification in work health and safety nursing, manage workplaces safety and health, group education, health education, management of other WHS nurses, research, writing and implementation of work health and safety.

"}]

actionsList.text:
There are multiple organisations, too numerous to list, which produce clinical guidelines for the Australian context. The Australian Government and National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) have also developed the Australian Clinical Practice Guidelines Portal https://www.clinicalguidelines.gov.au. This is a very useful starting point when searching for specific areas of interest. Some other guidelines are listed below:

  • National Asthma Council Australia Spirometry training and tools
  • Asthma resource kit: A resource for primary health care nurses
  • COPD X Guidelines: COPD X guidelines
  • Heart Foundation: Clinical Information (Guidelines, tools and other publications by condition)
  • Stroke Foundation: Clinical Guideline for Stroke Management
  • Cancer Council Australia: Clinical Guidelines
  • Diabetes Australia: Best Practice Guidelines
  • Kidney Health Australia: Kidney health resources
  • The National Health and Medical Research Council: Guidelines to reduce health risks from drinking alcohol.
  • Australian Government: The National Physical Activity and Sedentary Behaviour Guidelines

The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) produces a wide range of clinical guidelines to assist General Practitioners and nurses in their work, and recognises externally produced guidelines through RACGP endorsement. These resources are relevant to a variety of settings and are considered a valuable source of information. Their relevance is not limited to the General Practice environment.

The RACGP Red Book, 8th edition 17, provides evidence based guidelines from Australian and International sources and offers recommendations for everyday use with patients. It can be used as a guide to identify who is most at risk and for whom screening or preventative care is most appropriate.

If completing Medicare Benefit Schedule (MBS) health assessments you need to ensure that the collection of required assessment data and documentation meet regulatory requirements. The assessment templates are available through most of the clinical software packages or may be accessed from the Department of Health’s – Medicare Health Assessments Resource kit. Even workplaces who do not utilise the MBS billing, may find the templates found in the Department of Health’s – Medicare Health Assessments Resource kit useful.

aspects.title: Finding resources and support
aspects.text: Identify opportunities and/or funding for quality improvement, research and evaluation
aspects.examples:
• Identifies ideas for research activities
  • Identifies opportunities and/or funding for research opportunities
  • Involvement in clinical policy and research communities to identify deficits in evidence and identification of potential funding sources for practice or research development
aspects.onlineResources:
• Australian Primary Care Collaborative
  • Explore funding sources including ACN Grants and awards
  • PHC Research Conference
aspects.levels:
Foundation Practice

I’m learning how to support the implementation of evidence into practice where this has been shown to improve health outcomes and the quality of nursing care.

Intermediate Practice

I’m confident to implement evidence into practice where this has been shown to improve health outcomes and the quality of nursing care.

Advanced Practice 

I lead and guide by actively supporting the implementation of evidence into practice where this has shown to improve health outcomes and the quality of nursing care.

aspects.title: Health literacy
aspects.text: Applies a health literacy approach to improve the individual's engagement in their health and communication between the individual and primary health care team
aspects.examples:
• Introduce systems to reduce the risk of harm to consumers by improving communication and information exchange
  • Use “teach back” technique when checking the level of understanding of their condition, for an individual seeking care
  • Avoid the use of jargon in preparation of health related information

Intermediate Practice

Advanced Practice 

I lead and guide others to confidently practice clinical care that is holistic, person-centred and culturally safe.

aspects.title: Leadership
aspects.text: Engages in professional and organisational leadership within and beyond own setting
aspects.examples:
• Seeks leadership opportunities within own area of practice
  • Undertakes CPD with a focus on leadership skills
  • Leads programs of work focusing on the expanding the role of nursing in primary health care
aspects.onlineResources:
• Celebrate leadership as the everyday act of improving each other’s lives, Drew Dudley: Everyday leadership
  • Simon Sinek has a simple but powerful model for inspirational leadership all starting with a golden circle and the question "Why?" His examples include Apple, Martin Luther King, and the Wright brothers, How great leaders inspire action

Foundation Practice

I’m learning how to actively promote the role, value and professionalism of nursing, specifically the role of the nurse in primary health care.

Intermediate Practice

I’m confident when actively promoting the role, value and professionalism of nursing, specifically the role of the nurse in primary health care

Advanced Practice 

I lead and guide by actively promoting the role, value and professionalism of nursing, specifically the role of the nurse in primary health care

aspects.title: Learning environment
aspects.text: Facilitates and actively engages in cultivating an environment that improves learning
aspects.examples:
• As mentor, focus on the goals and professional development needs of the mentoree
  • Apply the NMBA’s “Enrolled nurse standards for practice” (2016) when acting as a supervisor
  • Apply educational based theories in the development of learning modules ?for colleagues

aspects.title: Personal Reflection
aspects.text: Demonstrates ability to undertake personal reflection of clinical practice
aspects.examples:
• Actively participate in reflective practice in a structured way, with colleagues and supervisor
  • Encourage a safe work environment to enable self expression and an openness to share experiences amongst colleagues
  • Use critical reflection to improve knowledge, skills and behaviour, enabling  a constant update to own practice

aspects.title: Planning care
aspects.text: Applies evidence-based clinical skills in planning nursing care to meet the needs of individuals accessing care
aspects.examples:
• Use a clinical audit tool to identify individuals with cardiovascular risk factors
  • Apply COPD-X guidelines when planning care for individuals with a diagnosis of COPD
  • Able to prioritise clinical workload in order of need
aspects.levels:
Foundation Practice

I am learning how to apply and carry out clinical care that is holistic, person-centred and culturally safe.

Intermediate Practice

I am confidently practicing clinical care that is holistic, person-centred and culturally safe.

Advanced Practice 

I lead and guide others to confidently practice clinical care that is holistic, person-centred and culturally safe.

aspects.title: Policies and procedures
aspects.text: Develops, implements or reviews policies and procedures
aspects.examples:
• Own clinical practice is informed by policies aligned with best practice guidelines
  • Contribute at an organisational level to development of policies and procedures
  • In conjunction with my local primary health network, contribute to policy development related to care coordination and service delivery
aspects.levels:
Foundation Practice

I’m learning how to contribute to the optimal functioning of the primary health care setting by coordinating care and assisting people to navigate through the health system.

Intermediate Practice

I confidently contribute to the optimal functioning of the primary health care setting by coordinating care and assisting people to navigate through the health system across care transitions.

Advanced Practice 

I lead strategies to improve the functioning of the primary health care setting by enhancing systems at an organisational level, process level and the level of the individual accessing care.

aspects.title: Population Health
aspects.text: Alignment of competence and clinical skills with population health needs to deliver targeted public health, health promotion and prevention to address the needs of the community
aspects.examples:
• Regularly review aggregated clinical data using a clinical audit tool (e.g. Pencat) to target “at risk” populations
  • Care is provided within a multidisciplinary team to maximise health outcomes for your community
  • Collaborate with local PHNs to design and implement programs based on evidence-based guidelines, aligned with identified local population needs
aspects.onlineResources:
RACGP: SNAP Guidelines: A population health guide to behavioural risk factors in general practice

APNA Primary Times Volume 11 Issue 3:A population based approached to palliative care

AIHW, Priority population groups

Nurse clinics in Australian General Practice: planning, implementation and evaluation

aspects.title: Scope of Practice
aspects.text: Optimises scope of practice through tailored education to ensure competence and confidence in area of practice
aspects.examples:
• Focuses CPD on increasing clinical skills to ensure care delivery is in line with needs of those accessing care and the broader community.
  • Uses own professional judgement about an identified activity which is beyond own capacity or scope of practice and initiates consultation with, or referral to, other members of the health care team
  • Undertakes postgraduate qualifications to optimise scope of practice and increase opportunities to lead improvements in primary health care
aspects.levels:
Foundation Practice

I am learning how to strengthen the knowledge and skills of the community accessing care to deliver quality health care and improve health outcomes.

Intermediate Practice

I’m confident in recognising and enhancing the knowledge and skills of the community accessing care and my colleagues, to deliver quality health care and improve health outcomes.

Advanced Practice 

I lead and guide others to expand their knowledge and skills, to deliver quality health care and improve health outcomes.

actions.text:
There are multiple organisations, too numerous to list, which produce clinical guidelines for the Australian context. The Australian Government and National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) have also developed the Australian Clinical Practice Guidelines Portal https://www.clinicalguidelines.gov.au. This is a very useful starting point when searching for specific areas of interest. Some other guidelines are listed below:

  • National Asthma Council Australia Spirometry training and tools
  • Asthma resource kit: A resource for primary health care nurses
  • COPD X Guidelines: COPD X guidelines
  • Heart Foundation: Clinical Information (Guidelines, tools and other publications by condition)
  • Stroke Foundation: Clinical Guideline for Stroke Management
  • Cancer Council Australia: Clinical Guidelines
  • Diabetes Australia: Best Practice Guidelines
  • Kidney Health Australia: Kidney health resources
  • The National Health and Medical Research Council: Guidelines to reduce health risks from drinking alcohol.
  • Australian Government: The National Physical Activity and Sedentary Behaviour Guidelines

The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) produces a wide range of clinical guidelines to assist General Practitioners and nurses in their work, and recognises externally produced guidelines through RACGP endorsement. These resources are relevant to a variety of settings and are considered a valuable source of information. Their relevance is not limited to the General Practice environment.

The RACGP Red Book, 8th edition 17, provides evidence based guidelines from Australian and International sources and offers recommendations for everyday use with patients. It can be used as a guide to identify who is most at risk and for whom screening or preventative care is most appropriate.

If completing Medicare Benefit Schedule (MBS) health assessments you need to ensure that the collection of required assessment data and documentation meet regulatory requirements. The assessment templates are available through most of the clinical software packages or may be accessed from the Department of Health’s – Medicare Health Assessments Resource kit. Even workplaces who do not utilise the MBS billing, may find the templates found in the Department of Health’s – Medicare Health Assessments Resource kit useful.

Engage with local council regarding local population health and wellness
actions.title: Increase knowledge of local population health needs

actions.text:
Develop key public health prevention strategies within your workplace such as the:

  • National Bowel Screening Program
  • National Cervical Screening Program
actions.title: Develop key public health prevention strategies

actions.text: Consider some short courses in evaluation- primary health / population health focus in evaluation.
actions.title: Consider some short courses

actions.text:
Consider joining your local APNA Nurse Network 
Contact your PHN and ask about their Nurse Network
Seek out someone in your workplace experienced in evaluation.
actions.title: Consider joining your local APNA Nurse Network

actions.text: Become involved in a special project related to evaluation within your organisation. For example, become part of a evaluation working group, or express interest in evaluating the patient experience through a patient survey, e.g. Telehealth consultation or the Patient Enablement and Satisfaction Survey (PESS).
actions.title: Become involved in a special project

actions.text: Consider undertaking post graduate qualifications - primary health / population health focus in evaluation
actions.title: Consider undertaking post graduate qualifications

actions.text: Seek a mentor from a colleague and local university or health service, who can assist you to evaluate care provision in your area of practice
actions.title: Seek a mentor from a colleague and local university

actions.text: Consider collaborating with your colleagues and local university or health service, to undertake a research project to evaluate care provision in your area of practice
actions.title: Consider collaborating with your colleagues to undertake research

actions.text:
You might like to review the APNA online learning course titled: Scope of Practice which is free to APNA members – here

Also review: Practice  Standards for Nurses working in General Practice and National Toolkit for Nurses in General Practice

The Framework for assessing national competency standards and other relevant guideline information found here and as a PDF . This is a set of tools and principles to assist nurses in the process of making decisions about whether specific tasks are within their individual scope of practice. It also provides a framework for nurses seeking to expand their individual scope of practice.
actions.title: Review the APNA online learning course

actions.text: Ensure there is a policy and procedure in place in your workplace which supports a particular procedure you perform, including skill review annually.
actions.title: Ensure there is a policy and procedure in place in your workplace

actions.text: Ensure regular review of the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (AHPRA) regulation documentation around scope of practice registration standards as these standards tend to update regularly.
actions.title: Ensure regular review of the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (AHPRA) regulation documentation

actions.text: Use existing frameworks such as annual reviews, skills assessments and the scope of practice framework documents from AHPRA to review, update and ensure you are working to your fullest scope of practice
actions.title: Use existing frameworks such as annual reviews, skills assessments and the scope of practice framework documents

roles.name: Enrolled Nurse
roles.title: Enrolled Nurse
roles.whatIs:
An Enrolled Nurse (EN) has completed a Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA) approved Diploma of Nursing program in order to practice. In addition, individuals must demonstrate the ability to meet the standards for ENs by the NMBA.

The EN works with the registered nurse (RN) as part of the health care team and demonstrates competence in the provision of person-centred care. Core practice generally requires the EN to work under the direct or indirect supervision of the RN. At all times, the EN retains responsibility for his/her actions and remains accountable in providing delegated nursing care. The need for the EN to have a named and accessible RN at all times and in all contexts of care for support and guidance is critical to patient safety.

Enrolled nurses, like other regulated health professionals, are required to undertake mandatory continuing professional development in order to maintain their competence to practice. Latest requirements by the NMBA can be found at:

http://www.nursingmidwiferyboard.gov.au/Registration-Standards.aspx

Enrolled Nurses collaborate and consult with health care recipients, their families and community as well as RNs and other health professionals, to plan, implement and evaluate integrated care that optimises outcomes for recipients and the systems of care. They are responsible for the delegated care they provide and self-monitor their work.
roles.whatIsTheirRole:
The EN role is capability to: 

  • provide direct and indirect care; 
  • engage in reflective and analytical practice; and 
  • demonstrate professional and collaborative practice.

Enrolled Nurses, where appropriate, educate and support other (unregulated) health care workers (however titled) related to the provision of care.

roles.pathways:
To become an Enrolled Nurse (EN) in Australia the minimum level of study is the Diploma of Nursing. The course is delivered through the Vocation Education and Training (VET) sector, through local TAFE or state/territory institutes of technology. Some private Registered Training Organisations are also approved to deliver the Diploma of Nursing. 

Some ENs choose to undertake additional study in their chosen specialty role, or for career development. In some workplaces, the title ‘Advanced practice EN’ is used to describe these nurses with additional knowledge and skills. The Advanced Diploma is also delivered through the VET sector.

In order to practice as an EN in Australia, a registration application is made to the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA).

For further information on how to become an EN in Australia please visit the NENA website (www.nena.org.au) or state/territory health department website.

roles.name: Midwife
roles.title: Midwife
roles.whatIs: A midwife is a health professional who has completed an approved program of study, such as a Bachelor of Midwifery, or a post graduate diploma or Master’s degree in midwifery, and is registered as a midwife with the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA). The overarching framework within which midwives in Australia work, is woman centred care. This recognises the right of a woman to self-determination, takes a holistic approach to her individual needs and supports her through the various phases of pregnancy, birth and the first 6 weeks of the postnatal period.
roles.whatIsTheirRole:
In Australia, midwives work in a number of settings including:

  • hospitals 
  • birthing centres 
  • community centres
  • rural and remote health services
  • general practice
  • women’s homes. 

They may be employed by health services or organisations, or self-employed as privately practising midwives. All midwives are expected to work within a defined scope of practice and conform to ongoing regulatory requirements that ensure they are safe and autonomous practitioners.

For information about the regulation of RNs including professional standards, codes and guidelines and scope of practice decision making tools see:

www.nursingmidwiferyboard.gov.au/Codes-Guidelines-Statements.aspx

  • Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (2010). National competency standards for the midwife.
  • Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (2016). Registered nurse standards for practice.
  • Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (2008). Code of Ethics for Nurses in Australia
  • Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (2008). Code of Professional Conduct for Nurses in Australia.
  • Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (2010). Professional boundaries for nurses
  • Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (2016). Registered nurse standards for practice.
roles.pathways:
There are now two main pathways to midwifery in Australia.  The first is to complete a Bachelor of Midwifery.  This option is now available in most states in Australia.  A Bachelor of Midwifery is a three year undergraduate degree which students who do not have a nursing qualification can complete.

The second way to become a midwife is to complete a Bachelor of Nursing degree and then to complete a Graduate Diploma or Master of Midwifery.  These programs are generally 12-18 months in length.

roles.name: Nurse Practitioner
roles.title: Nurse Practitioner
roles.whatIs: Nurse practitioner is an advanced practice nurse endorsed by the NMBA who has direct clinical contact and practises within their scope under the legislatively protected title ‘nurse practitioner’ under the National Law. The scope of practice of the nurse practitioner will vary depending on the context in which the NP practices.

roles.pathways:
When applying for endorsement as a nurse practitioner, a nurse must be able to demonstrate all of the following:

1. Current general registration as a registered nurse in Australia with no conditions or undertakings relating to unsatisfactory professional performance or unprofessional conduct.

2. The equivalent of three years’ full-time experience (5,000 hours) at the clinical advanced nursing practice level, within the past six years, from the date when the complete application seeking endorsement as a nurse practitioner is received by the NMBA.

3. Successful completion of:

an NMBA-approved program of study leading to endorsement as a nurse practitioner, or

a program that is substantially equivalent to an NMBA-approved program of study leading to endorsement as a nurse practitioner as determined by the NMBA.

4. Compliance with the NMBA’s Nurse practitioner standards for practice.

roles.name: Registered Nurse
roles.title: Registered Nurse
roles.whatIs:
A Registered Nurse (RN) must have successfully completed an approved Bachelor degree (or, where relevant, an approved post graduate qualification). The minimum duration of the course of study must be equivalent to six semesters of full time study.

A newly qualified (or ‘entry to practice’ or ‘foundation’) registered nurse is expected to be able to practise independently and to take responsibility and accountability for the care they provide. They are also expected to take responsibility for the delegation of care to enrolled nurses (ENs) and other health care workers. Delegation by the RN includes taking into consideration the education, level of training and individual scope of practice of the EN or other health care worker, and the context of care.

Registered Nurses working in clinical settings are educated to assess, plan, implement and evaluate nursing care provided to patients and clients across age, cultural and social spectrums. Their work may be undertaken independently or more commonly in collaboration with individuals and the multidisciplinary health care team in order to achieve goals and health outcomes.

Registered Nurses, like other regulated health professionals, are required to undertake mandatory continuing professional development in order to maintain their competence to practice. Latest requirements by the Nursing Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA) can be found at:

www.nursingmidwfieryboard.gov.au/Registration-Standards.aspx

An individual RN’s scope of practice is determined by a number of factors, such as their level of education, seniority, time in a specific role or speciality, and their individual level of competence. The scope of practice of an individual RN is likely to be more specific than the scope of the profession.
roles.whatIsTheirRole:
• Every registered nurse must be able to demonstrate competence as described in the NMBA Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse (2006). Key roles which nurses working in primary health care may participate in include:health promotion
  • Illness prevention
  • Antenatal and postnatal care
  • Child and family health nursing
  • Treatment and care of sick people
  • Rehabilitation and palliation
  • Community development
  • Population and public health
  • Education and research
  • Policy development and advocacy
