postCards.text:
The next step in my nursing journey is... 
to complete my post graduate degree in rural and remote health, specialising in primary health care, to deliver the best possible care!

I feel valued as a nurse when...
patients call & want to speak with me.

One thing nurses across primary health care have in common is...
passion for looking after people in the community.

I feel valued as a nurse when...
patients and families express their thanks for the care our practice provides as a whole team.

I feel valued as a nurse when...
my opinion is valued and respected.

I feel valued as a nurse when...
my patients tell me how much I've helped them and thank me for my work as a nurse - often through Education and translating medical jargon into something they can understand.

I feel valued as a nurse when...
I see or hear about a patient who has changed (positive change) due to an intervention I did. LOVE IT!

definitions.name: Culturally safe care
definitions.text: Culturally safe care is perceived by the health service user as respectful and sensitive to their culture, beliefs and identity, free from discrimination and empowering them in decision-making. An important aspect of cultural safety is that the health professional has insight into ways in which their own culture and cultural values may impact on clients.

definitions.name: Individual accessing care
definitions.text: Throughout the RN Career and Education Framework, individual accessing care is inclusive of all those who are personally significant to the client and are concerned with their management, and client permission has been given for their involvement. Individual accessing care can be interchangeable used with client, patient, person, people.

definitions.name: Advocate
definitions.text: Advocating involves supporting and promoting the rights and interests of individuals, assisting individuals to achieve or maintain their rights and empowering and representing their needs.

definitions.name: Scope of Practice
definitions.text: Scope of Practice is that in which nurses are educated, competent to perform and permitted by law. The actual scope of practice is influenced by the context in which the nurse practises, the health needs of people, the level of competence and confidence of the nurse and the policy requirements of the service provider. (source: NMBA)

definitions.name: Person-centred
definitions.text: Person-centred practice is collaborative and respectful partnership built on mutual trust and understanding through good communication. Each person is treated as an individual with the aim of respecting people’s ownership of their health information, rights and preferences while protecting their dignity and empowering choice. Person-centred practice recognises the role of family and community with respect to cultural and religious diversity. (source: NMBA)

definitions.name: Evidence-based
definitions.text: Evidence-based practice is accessing and making judgements to translate the best available evidence, which includes the most current, valid, and available research findings into practice. (source: NMBA)

definitions.name: Research governance
definitions.text: Research governance is a framework through which organisations are accountable for the scientific quality, ethical acceptability and safety of the research they allow to be conducted under their direction and leadership. (source: RMH)

definitions.name: Validated
definitions.text: A validated screening tool is a tool that has been demonstrated to satisfy certain nursing and health care standards so that it will reliably assess patients, clients, individuals accessing care.

definitions.name: Clinical risk management systems
definitions.text:
An effective risk management system is one incorporating strategies to:
•	identify risks/hazards
•	assess the likelihood of the risks occurring and the severity of the consequences if the risks do occur, and
•	prevent the occurrence of the risks, or minimise their impact. (source: NMBA)

definitions.name: Interdisciplinary
definitions.text:
An interdisciplinary approach involves team members from different disciplines working collaboratively, with a common purpose, to set goals, make decisions and share resources and responsibilities. (source: Department of Human Services 2008, Health independence programs guidelines, State Government, Melbourne.)

A team of clinicians from different disciplines, together with the patient, undertakes assessment, diagnosis, intervention, goal-setting and the creation of a care plan. The patient, their family and carers are involved in any discussions about their condition, prognosis and care plan. (source: Jessup RL 2007, ‘Interdisciplinary versus multidisciplinary care teams: do we understand the difference?’, Australian Health Review, 31(3):330-331.)

definitions.name: Multidisciplinary
definitions.text: A multidisciplinary approach involves team members working independently to create discipline-specific care plans that are implemented simultaneously, but without explicit regard to their interaction. (source: Continuing Care Section, Programs Branch, Metropolitan Health and Aged Care Services Division, Department of Human Services 2003, Improving care for older people: a policy for health services, State Government of Victoria, Melbourne.)

definitions.name: Teach back
definitions.text: “Teach back” is when you ask an individual accessing care or colleague to repeat in their own words what you have explained to them. This provides a chance to check for understanding and, if necessary, re-teach information. (source: VicHealth)

definitions.name: Targeted
definitions.text: This is defining a subgroup of the population based on common characteristics and providing information in a manner consistent with how this population would access health related information. For example, targeted health promotions such as Drinking Nightmare which is the National Binge Drinking Campaign. Along with a range of initiatives, it aims to reduce harms associated with drinking to intoxication by young Australians.

definitions.name: Value-based
definitions.text: Value-based healthcare is where we both measure the costs and resources we use for our healthcare services and also measure the amount of health benefit we get back from our healthcare services. It could be we give years of life to patients by reducing mortality or we improve the quality of years of life of patients by removing morbidity. (source: Professor, Nick Graves, Health Economist and Academic Director of The Australian Centre for Health Services Innovation (AusHSI)

definitions.name: Practice of inquiry
definitions.text: Is where a set of small-group, practice-based learning and improvement methods is used to help nurses better manage case-based clinical uncertainty. ‘Practice of inquiry’ can occur when nurses meet or conduct handover to present dilemma cases, share clinical experience, review evidence for blending with experience, and draw implications for practice improvement.

definitions.name: Health literacy
definitions.text: Health literacy is the degree to which individuals have capacity to obtain, process and understand the health information and services they need to make appropriate health decisions. (source: 1Op cit ACSQH Health literacy stocktake (2012) 2. Department of Health Victoria (DoH Vic) Health literacy: enabling communication and participation in health Background Paper (2013))

definitions.name: Clinical governance
definitions.text: Clinical governance is the integrated systems, processes, leadership and culture that are at the core of providing safe, effective, accountable and person-centred healthcare underpinned by continuous improvement. (source: Vic Health)

definitions.name: Reflective practice
definitions.text: This is seen as a means of improving clinical practice and quality of care, through exploring and evaluating one’s understanding of a problem rather than simply trying to solve it. (Leung, Pluye, Grad, & Weston, 2010)

definitions.name: Informal education
definitions.text: Informal education is the acquisition of knowledge and skills that usually occurs outside the formal curriculum (i.e. life experiences). (source: VOECD)

definitions.name: Critical reflection
definitions.text: Critical reflection is seen as an extension critical thinking. It challenges the nurse to think about their practice and ideas and then it enables you to step-back and examine your thinking by asking probing questions. It asks nurses to not only delve into the past and look at the present but importantly it asks you to speculate about the future and act. (Department of Education and Training, Victorian Government).

definitions.name: Critical thinking
definitions.text: Critical thinking is where a nurse uses a variety of thinking strategies and the best available evidence in making decisions and providing safe, quality nursing practice within person-centred and evidence-based frameworks. (source: NMBA)

definitions.name: Holistic
definitions.text: Nurses accurately conduct comprehensive and systematic assessments. They analyse information and data and communicate outcomes as the basis for practice.

definitions.name: Personal and professional reflection
definitions.text: Reflecting on your personal and professional attributes to identify learning needs and develop new ideas and insights to inform your future practice.

definitions.name: Campaigns
definitions.text: A health campaign is the use of media to promote health interventions and strategies.

reasons.title: Flexible hours
reasons.text: Sick and tired of the grind of shift work? One of the great things about working in primary health care is the flexible working hours it allows. There are considerably more opportunities to work within standard business hours, and nurses can often fit work around family needs. For example, school nurses work school hours and nurses in general practice often work 9am to 5pm.

reasons.title: Autonomy in decision making
reasons.text: Nurses in primary health care can have wonderful autonomy – with plenty of freedom to guide their own working experience. This comes with broad responsibility, alongside working collaboratively with a team, all making for a positive, challenging and satisfying career option.

reasons.title: Broad scope of practice
reasons.text: Nursing is a continuously evolving discipline – and primary health care is right at the forefront. Scientific and technological advancement and the demands of the community require nurses to constantly gain new knowledge and skills. And nowhere are the margins of nursing practice expanding faster than in primary health care.

reasons.title: Nurse-led clinics
reasons.text: Nurse-led clinics allow you to run the show. While you still work as part of a multidisciplinary team, you’re the primary provider of care and have a patient caseload. Not only do these clinics benefit patients, they can also provide considerable professional satisfaction for nurses.

reasons.title: Patient-centred care
reasons.text: In primary health care, you get to put the patient firmly at the centre of care. This is because nursing allows you to provide healthcare that is respectful of, and responsive to, the preferences, needs and values of patients and consumers.

reasons.title: No day is ever the same
reasons.text: The day to day role of a nurse in primary health care is always different, swinging between unplanned reactive care to planned coordinated care. For example, one day you might be responding to unexpected presentations (e.g. triage, wound care, immunisation, facilitating referrals), whereas on another you may operate more autonomously with your own appointment schedule (e.g. a dedicated women’s health clinic, chronic disease care planning, aged care health assessment home visits).
reasons.textPrev: No day is ever the same

reasons.title: The chance to become part of the community
reasons.text: Nurses can make a big impact on community health. They do so by providing a wide range of health promotion programs, as well as services to children, young people, adults, and families. For example, some primary health care nurses work within schools to provide health-related programs for students and staff.
reasons.textPrev: The chance to become part of the community

reasons.title: Varied environments outside of a hospital setting
reasons.text: Rather than being limited to the confines of a hospital, primary health care can be provided in a variety of settings such as the home, community-based settings, women’s health clinics and general practice. Within these settings, there are sub-specialties. For example, a community health service may have specialist programs for refugees and asylum seekers, while a general practice may specialise in areas such as maternal and child health, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health or mental health.
reasons.textPrev: Varied environments outside of a hospital setting

reasons.title: Less organisational hierarchy
reasons.text: Primary health care is often less hierarchical than a hospital. This means that nurses benefit from the many advantages of a flatter management hierarchy, such as elevated levels of responsibility, improved coordination and speed of communication between the team and an easier decision-making process within the organisation.

reasons.title: Varying job prospects
reasons.text: There are many roles in primary health care that delve into different skill sets (clinical care, care coordination, teaching, project management, etc.) and enable nurses to work with diverse populations and health professionals. No team or job is ever the same – just another reason why primary health care is so exciting and rewarding.

reasons.title: You can actually make a difference
reasons.text: This is your chance to work at the coalface of healthcare in Australia, as nurses in primary health care are at the forefront of care coordination, disease prevention and health promotion. The world is your oyster in primary health care, with an opportunity to go beyond the medical model of health and address the complex issues that affect the wider community to make a real impact.
reasons.textPrev: You can actually make a difference
